1012.sys_summ:
Instructing a child in truth is the primary reason for choosing an educational method, whether that method be homeschooling, public school, or private school.
Home schooled children are often accused of not being able to make those.
Studies by the National Home Education Research Institute also show that homeschooled children fare noticeably better on tests than their publicly schooled peers.
In spite of their motivations, public school educators continue to stumble.
The challenge for the home schooling movement shifted from making home education possible to keeping it free.

Parents of private school students tend to be more involved in their children's education.
Many parents choose accredited programs so that their child is receiving the same education as other children of their age, but at their own pace.
Parents operating private schools to educate only their own children are not required to obtain city business licenses.
Many minority families are finding that homeschooling is an alternative to that of public school education (Bauman, 2001).

Homeschool parents need not worry if their child learned something in school.
Parents need only test if they are homeschooling under local school district supervision.
Public schools, in general, are failing our children academically, morally, and philosophically.
Homeschooling is frowned upon by the public schools and by political governments for obvious reasons.
Parents have the absolute right to withdraw their child from public school and use any other legal option to educate their child.
Critics often argue that homeschooling keeps children from socializing with a diverse group of peers.

Parents, it is noted, are taking advantage of all kinds of resources - websites, special publications, libraries, community colleges, tutors for some subjects, various associations where their children can acquire social skills - and are doing so at a cost much more affordable than private schools.
Certified teachers and highly trained school administrators had no reason to believe that parents could cover the basic academic subjects, much less provide the social interactions that were offered in the public schools.

Surely this is tantamount to these homeschoolers saying that homeschooling doesn't work -- just what the anti-homeschool people need to turn the system back against homeschooling!
Many of us were homeschooling our children until Wildcat opened and it has been an ideal middle ground between homeschooling and school.
I believe that home schooling has shown that students gain more autonomy in a home schooled setting.
The flip side of homeschooling is the possibility of the parent/parents injecting far more prejudice and political attitudes than would be found in a classroom.

Smokers narrate their smoking experiences to their peers thus persuading them to start the habit.
Anyone who tried their first cigarette before the age of sixteen was deliberately defying the law, as well as their parents and teachers.
Teens should be encouraged to develop their own relationships with members of their diabetes team.
Many teens do not like checking their blood sugar levels and avoid doing it.
Peer pressure can be unbelievably hard to cope with.
Parents also need to understand that diabetes routines may become a target for risk-taking behaviours.

This surge in teen smoking is due to a number of factors, including the targeting of minors in tobacco industry advertising, coupled with an alarming decline of concern among teenagers about the dangers of cigarette use.
Like many other teenage disciplinary issues, convincing teens to stop smoking can be a challenge.
We all know that peer pressure is one of the most common reasons teenagers start smoking, by allowing a forum and room for peer dialogue could be the right medicine a teen needs to stop smoking or not start at all.

1021.sys_summ:
There is a tendency for adults to either avoid involvement or to intervene at a very superficial level when they witness bullying behaviour.
The parents of two of the three boys involved in her son's bullying did not even show up for a meeting called by the principal.
Avoid attempts to mediate a bullying situation.
Key elements include conflict resolution training for all staff members, social skills building for victims, positive leadership skills training for bullies, intervention techniques for those who neither bully nor are bullied and the development of parental support.

Teens may be too afraid to tell their parents they are being bullied.
Bullying or acts of bullying should not be tolerated in the school or the community.
Bullying is a form of victimization, not a conflict.
Teachers are dealing with bullying on a daily basis without let up.
The stress of dealing with bullies can make kids feel sick.
Punishing a bully is often the most common reaction in schools.
Learn to recognise bullying as soon as it starts.
Parents can and should be teaching their children proper morals.
Bullies use intimidation to keep others from noticing their weaknesses.

Parenting an adolescent is never easy, and when your teen is using or abusing drugs or alcohol, this transitional period is especially complex.
Adolescents whose parents have ongoing conversations with them about not trying drugs or alcohol are up to 50% less likely to try these substances.
Parents should ingrain in their kids the information that alcohol and drugs can be harmful before they are faced with these choices.
Studies show that kids are up to 50% less likely to get involved with substance abuse if their parent talked to them about saying no to drugs and alcohol.

Parents should feel empowered when it comes to keeping their kids off drugs.
Talk to your kids, not just about drugs but in general.
Ask parents to define problems associated with drug use rather than simply focusing on drug use itself.
Keep talking with your kids about substance abuse.
Adolescents abuse prescription drugs more than just about any other substance.
Listen with love and empathy to your children.
Keep your focus on the use of drugs.
Paying attention to this will help you know how your child is feeling.
Teaching your kids to make choices is the best anyone can do.

Right click here (93KB) to download a MS Word Document written for NSW welfare workers on managing high risk youth with alcohol and other drug problems. 
Parents are often very distressed about their son/daughter's drug use. 
They need their fears, anxieties and concerns to be fully heard. 
However, do not deepen problems. 
Rather look for opportunities to congratulate on their management of distress. 
Often only one parent will make the initial contact. 
Assess the other parent's involvement and point of view. 
If possible, have both parents present for further sessions.

" I want drugs".
Some kids who use drugs are self-medicating.
These young people are not using drugs just to feel good.
These parents cannot do it on their own.
here are some examples of advice from parents for other parents: Because they are using an illicit drug, they are often exposed to harder drugs and to drug dealers.
It seems many parents believe that their kids are immune to drugs, but drugs are no respecter of persons.
or "Why do people take drugs?" Vehicle batteries are often stolen in northern counties because they can bring in $8 each to use for drug money.

If You Suspect Your Child Has a Substance Abuse Problem: What You Can Do Now If you suspect your child might be drinking or taking drugs, talk to your child's school.
Barun notes that if you suspect one of your child's friends is pressuring your child to do drugs, you have every right to tell your child not to see that friend.
Let me be clear: there is no other reason for your child to pal around with kids who do drugs.
The only person that can get you kid off drugs in your son or daughter.
Now as an adult I do not know how to parent my own children.

Families with high parental involvement in their children's schools are more likely to visit a library, museum or historical site with their children, and are more likely to have high educational expectations for their children.
Chrispeels and Rivero (2001) previously found that after participating in this education program, parents reported dramatic changes in their parenting behaviors, such as praising their child, engaging in less physical punishment for mistakes, and establishing rules and limits to television viewing, which supported more time for learning activities.

Involving parents in their own children's education at home is not enough.
Parent involvement is most effective when it is comprehensive, long-lasting, and well-planned.
Parents do not have to be well-educated to help.
Children tend to work harder at their studies when parents are involved.
Learn about the studying your child is expected to do.
Talk with your child about the importance of attending school regularly.
Teach your children to finish what they start.
Schools need to be mindful of these experiences when developing courses and training sessions for parents.

Gordon's six types of parent involvement (Gordon & Breivogel, 1976) are: (a) the traditional type of parent involvement type (the parent as audience or bystander-observer); (b) parents as decision makers (as in School Advisory Committees or Parent Teacher Associations [PTAs] in which parents participate in school decision making activities); (c) parents begin as classroom volunteers; (d) parent as a paid paraprofessional or teacher's aide; (e) parents as learners (e.g., participate in child development or parenting classes); and (f) parents as teachers of their own children at home.

If you're an adult returning to school, you might have some willies. 
What will it be like? 
Will you be good at studying? 
How will you be in the classroom? 
Will you be ready? 
No worries. 
We've got some great stuff to help you be ready: from balancing school, life and work to priming your study skills, from getting psyched up for learning to preparing you for participating in the classroom. 
Returning to school involves more than reading a textbook and taking tests. 
Are you ready? 
It's not always easy.

Age is what schools have traditionally used as the deciding factor to determine a child's readiness for kindergarten.
While age does play an important role in kindergarten enrollment, both preschool and kindergarten teachers are also now looking at a variety of skills and behaviors to determine if a child is ready.
Kindergarten teachers recommend that before children start kindergarten, they attend a preschool or nursery school program for at least two half days a week.
Preschool teachers often have a pretty good idea of whether children are ready for kindergarten.

And many independent schools have introduced a transitional or Pre-K year for children who are not ready for kindergarten.
Some experts believe that preschool may even be more important for kids who've been at home with their parents, to help get them ready for the move to kindergarten.
I strongly encourage you and your child to visit the school before school starts.

Tips for Helping Children of Different Ages and Stages Potty training never goes exactly the way you think it will. 
Even if your child seems highly eager and ready when you start, there are bound to be bumps in the road. 
Getting a variety of advice can help you manage the unique circumstances you'll encounter with your own child. 
Once you feel your child is ready, you'll need to take into consideration his individual personality and needs to determine how to teach him to use the potty. 
The Resistant Child You should be prepared for setbacks and resistance , however.

Study 10 is important to view within the context of the new cellphone industry push to market cellphones to children.
Some law-enforcement officials like the idea of enabling "instant check-in" with parents, but they say cellphones in the hands of young children raise some safety concerns.
In France the health minister, Roselyne Bachelot, has taken such concerns public, issuing an alert in January urging parents to limit use, reducing childrens telephone calls to no more than six minutes.
"Cell Phones are not needed, especially if all the other kids have them.

Parents want to be in touch with their kids," said John Breyault, who authored a new guide on tweens and cellphones for the National Consumers League (NCL) in Washington, D.C. Picking up Brandon outside Sutter Middle School last week, his mom, Elizabeth Gonzales, said he got his first phone at 10 "for safety reasons." Even when he's outside with friends in their midtown Sacramento neighborhood, she likes knowing Brandon can call home in any emergency.
And so-called "tweens", kids ages 9 to 12, may be the fastest-growing cellphone market out there.

Physical : your child being hit, kicked pinched, any form of violence Parents can get in big trouble when their kids skip school , sometimes even facing fines and jail time themselves.
If a parent SENDS the child the parent should not be held accountable for the child skipping out.
Officers have an option of giving kids a warning, taking them home, or booking them if the child is suspended or has been expelled, and the parents can't be reached.
Teachers, principals, parents, and lunchroom helpers at school can all help to stop bullying.

Illness & disability Special education and mainstream classes If you have a disability that affects how you learn, you may be put in a mainstream class but be given extra attention to help you learn. 
Or, you may be put in a special education class with other kids who have disabilities. 
If you are in a mainstream class, it is because you, your parents, and your teachers have decided it's the best place for you to learn. 
Even so, you may need help with certain things. 
If something is out of your reach or you have a question about the assignment, don't be afraid to ask.

Besides teaching the usual school subjects, many schools also offer special classes for kids with disabilities to help them learn life skills.
However, many teachers will attempt to motivate all thirty, unique and disparate students in the class by using one, solitary approach.
Walking Away From Peer Pressure Talking to a parent, teacher, or school counselor can help you feel much better and prepare you for the next time you face peer pressure.

If you're on the outside of a clique and you want to be friends with someone who's in it, invite that person to do something with you. But it's better for everyone if homeschooling isn't chosen just as an escape from school or problems there, such as bullying . You canï¿½t say, "I understand he has difficulty reading, but I will not tolerate his continually losing his homework." It can really help to have at least one other peer, or friend, who is willing to say "no," too. The kids would likely egg him on. Modify your methods. Donï¿½t take it personally.

Bullying can make kids not want to play outside or go to school.
For example, if your child is being bullied, you will need to work with the school to make sure your child is protected and that it stops.
As both parent and teacher, I agree with one of the main points, that of finding out what the main problem is behind the negative behaviors, but I disagree that there should be no further consequence at home for poor choices kids make at school.
You may also feel judged-and blamed-by teachers and other parents for what your child does at school.

What is it and What Can You Do About It? 
Bullies are becoming an increasing problem in schools across America. 
Learn how to recognize bullies and bullying. 
Learn the signs that can tell you if your child is being bullied -- or might be one doing the bullying. 
And learn what you can do about bullying! Symptoms to look for if you suspect that your child may be a bullying victim A child who may be the victim of school bullying may be reluctant to tell his parents out of shame or fear.

In recognition of this growing problem, 41 states now have anti-bullying laws (www.bullypolice.org). 
Currently many anti-bullying bills are under consideration in the Massachusetts legislature*. 
These bills call for schoolwide strategies to address bullying and for school districts to formulate prevention and intervention policies and procedures for reporting and investigating bullying. 
For example, in the fall of 2009, responses to a Massachusetts Advocates for Children online survey asked about the extent of bullying against children on the autism spectrum.

When parents of children attending (or who recently attended) Jewish day schools were asked to describe their feelings about being Jewish, over 90 per cent of respondents were strongly or extremely conscious of feeling Jewish (see Table 3.2).
Many families send their child to The Jewish Center Nursery School precisely because it is "Jewish," that is, Jewish life and particularly Shabbat are revered.
The Conservative movement defines a Jew as a person born to a Jewish mother or converted to Judaism.
The non-Jewish parent is made to feel pretty welcome.

The Javits Act does not fund local gifted education programs.

Federal loans are approved based on a variety of factors, like financial need, but not on credit history or lack of one; this means that a student with weak or no credit history can receive federal loans.
Here are the names of some of the most common federal student loans not requiring credit check: Stafford loans, Perkin loans, and Grad Plus loans.
The federal Graduate PLUS loan is approved based off of credit history; however, these loans generally have a less-stringent credit review than private, non-federal loans.

"Cyber bullying is defined as online material that threatens or raises concerns about violence against others, suicide or other selfharm.
Cyber bullying is defined as the use of online tools to harass someone.
Cyber-bullying (v.) :: when a child, preteen or teen is tormented, threatened, harassed, humiliated, embarrassed or otherwise targeted by another child, preteen or teen using the Internet, interactive and digital technologies or mobile phones.
Cyber bullying is a very difficult form of bullying to prevent and to police.

Cyber Bullying General Information Bullies are notorious for tormenting their victims face to face - usually at school - on the playground or in the cafeteria. 
But in recent years the Internet has not only increased the ability to bully at school, but has brought the problem into our homes and elsewhere - actually just about anywhere - at any time. 
Cyber bullying is the repeated use of information technology, including e-mail, instant messaging, blogs, chat rooms, pagers, cell phones, and gaming systems, to deliberately harass, threaten or intimidate others.

Include a section on cyber bullying in the student handbook.
- Make the consequences of cyber bullying very clear so students know what will happen if they act inappropriately.
Be sure to add a section that outlines the school's right to discipline a student for cyber bullying outside of school if the actions compromise the safety of the victim or have a negative effect on the victim at school.
- Make students aware that you know about cyber bullying and it will not be tolerated in your school.
Be sure to reference the "cyber bullying section" in the student handbook as well.

Student bullying is one of the most frequently reported discipline problems at school: 21% of elementary schools, 43% of middle schools, and 22% of high schools reported problems with bullying in 2005-06.
Cyber bullies may use the internet to send intimidating and threatening emails to others, create hostile Web sites, post inaccurate and embarrassing information in blogs, ignore kids who send them messages, and pose as people other than themselves in chat rooms.
Cyber-bullying is similar to other types of bullying, except it takes place online or through text messages sent to cell phones.

Learning disabilities are neurological differences in processing information that severely limit a person's ability to learn in a specific skill area.
Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is not a learning disability, but it definitely can affect a person's ability to learn.
Your child is not defined by his or her learning disability.
Parents and preschool teachers are often the first to see early signs of learning disabilities.
Parents of children with learning disabilities need to recognize that children with learning disabilities require exceptional amounts of energy.

Patsy and Edward Pastrano had no idea their bright, young son Gabe might have a learning disability until he entered second grade in his Montessori school and learning began to involve more and more abstract concepts. "He's very smart but he would learn something and then it was gone," Patsy Pastrano says. "He was also very distracted by other things in his environment." A teacher recommended that Gabe, then 8, be tested at the Children's Learning Institute (CLI) at The University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston.

"Our hypothesis is that secure attachment could reduce the risk for childhood obesity by preventing frequent or exaggerated stress responses from disrupting the normal functioning and development of the systems that affect energy balance and body weight.
Energy stored equates to weight gain, and energy intake is calories consumed from food and beverages.
In one of the studies, blood pressure and nutritional intake were also measured.
Ways for families to be active together to promote exercise and limit TV are emphasized as well as issues of food safety and choking hazards.

Children whose parents are overweight or obese are at higher risk for becoming obese themselves, studies have shown.
Obesity is a problem that is often shared by both parents and their children.
Children and adults alike who are obese or overweight are more likely to feel stress, and overweight children are more likely to report that their parents were often or always stressed over the past month.
All children with overweight/obese parents and at risk of becoming so themselves, should be monitored for unhealthy weight gain from birth.

MANY parents are ''in complete denial'' about their child's weight, obesity specialists say.
Parents need to establish healthy habits early in life.
Overweight children are very likely to become overweight adults.
Parents should be encouraged to teach and role model healthy lifestyle behaviours for their young children.
Obese children are subject to teasing and can be socially isolated by their peers.
 Limit the amount of time your child engages in sedentary activities.
 Ensure that your child has a trustworthy adult confidant.
Eating Disorders are not uncommon in our society today.

One Term, Many Definitions: "Special Needs" is an umbrella underneath which a staggering array of diagnoses can be wedged. 
Children with special needs may have mild learning disabilities or profound cognitive impairment; food allergies or terminal illness; developmental delays that catch up quickly or remain entrenched; occasional panic attacks or serious psychiatric problems. 
The designation is useful for getting needed services, setting appropriate goals, and gaining understanding for a child and stressed family.

One study, in the New England Journal of Medicine, found that for a child under 10, having an obese parent more than doubled the child's risk for becoming an obese adult.
For children, counting fat grams and calories isn't as important as watching portions and making healthy choices, said Terrill Bravender, M.D., a pediatrician with the Center for Nutritional Disorders and Obesity at Duke Children's Hospital and Health Center.
The Director of the US National Poll on Children's Health has confirmed that obesity heads the list of children's health concerns for the fourth straight year.

(e) Parents are encouraged to contact their child(ren)'s teacher(s) throughout the school year.

When our oldest son was in elementary school, he suffered from a very hot temper that tended to get him in trouble both at home and at school. 
One afternoon in about fifth grade, he and another boy in our neighborhood got in a fight at lunch recess and was sent to the principal's office. 
The principal knew our son was a good student who just let his emotions get out of control from time to time. 
During their meeting, he learned that Spencer was an avid reader, and he introduced him to the books written by Louis L'Amour .

International students are eligible to receive a private student loan as long as they have a US citizen or a permanent resident cosigns the loan.
Students are not required to make interest or principal payments until 6 months after graduation.
Students can defer their loan repayments and begin repaying the loan after graduation.
This means there's only one private student loan payment each month.
It is a long process and complicated phrase but really easy to understand.
Existing students will be sent an application form directly by their LEA.

Federal student loans are not based on credit, but on the borrower desire to receive financial aid.
Federal student loans are a desirable form of financial aid, as they have lower interest rates than many private student loans, and in some cases can be subsidized, meaning the government pays interest on the loan while the borrower is in school.
Federal financial aid is offered to all students in need irrespective of their area of specialization, and federal loans have lower interest rates and more flexible repayment terms than do private student loans for nursing students or otherwise.

Parents starting students with home schooling in ninth grade may discover their students need more self-discipline and good study habits than they anticipated.
And when students are unruly or even violent, who can blame teachers and administrators for punishing them, using the methods that are spelled out in the school's code of conduct.

ECD 79 - Anti-Bias Curriculum for Young Children (3 units) Developing approaches which help young children and the adults who care for them to enhance human diversity, recognize social bias, and take action for their own and others' behalf. 3 hours. 
Grading Option: OP Transfer: CSU ECD 80 - Advanced Topics in Childhood Development (1-3 units) Development and presentation of advanced topics in Early Childhood Development. 
Emphasis on creative arts, math and science, music and movement. 
Prerequisite: Early Childhood Development 63 (completed with a grade of "C" or higher). 1-3 hours.

Parents who are unable to cope with their own stress and anxiety can often unknowingly trigger these disorders in their kids.
These are the children who spend their time anticipating the worst.
They may be in the shadow of children whose more disruptive difficulties claim the immediate attention of parents and teachers.
Even parents who never loved school may be baffled, embarrassed or frustrated by the child's behavior.
Obviously parents can't predict and prepare for everything, so teaching a child to be more flexible and think through changes will also help.

sleep problems: your child might either have difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep (child might wake up several times every night) Students with test anxiety often need to practice test taking or simulating the test-taking experience to control or manage their anxiety.
Forcing a child with social anxiety to attend school can also trigger a panic attack, which has overwhelming physical and emotional sensations as well.
Many times children will improve with the help of anti-anxiety or anti-depressive medication, such as Prozac, Paxil, or Zoloft.

When the anxiety experienced by a young person starts to affect their general functioning, they may not just be feeling stressed - they may be suffering from an anxiety disorder.

Here's how you can help your child cope with feelings of depression. 
Difficulty: Average Time Required: Varies Here's How: Reassure your child that depression is not something to be ashamed of nor is he crazy. 
All of us feel sad in response to sad situations. 
Some of us have an illness that makes it harder for us to recover from sadness. 
Give your child the right to have these feelings. 
Children can easily get the idea that it's not okay to feel depressed and start to hide their feelings rather than deal with them in a healthy way.

A child with major depression feels depressed almost every day.
In kids, depression can appear as "bad moods" or irritability that persists for a long time, even if a child doesn't acknowledge being sad.
Unlike major depression, dysthymia does not severely interfere with day-to-day functioning but the "down mood" is a pervasive part of the child's world.

Understanding ADHD in Preschoolers What does a parent do when their four-year-old child seems to be into everything, perpetually on-the-go, can't sit still long enough to finish his snack or listen to a storybook, gets distracted easily, moves from one unfinished activity to the next, throws major tantrums when frustrated, interrupts conversations, snatches items impulsively from the hands of another, doesn't slow down enough to follow directions and is restless and squirmy? 
Could this child have ADHD ? 
Diagnosing ADHD in a child this young is tricky.

- If your child is sleep deprived because he or she regularly resists sleep, consider how your child views bedtime.
Have a relaxing bedtime routine that ends in the room where the child sleeps.
But when a toddler is waking up many times through the night, or a preschooler refuses to go to sleep at bedtime, parents don't know what to do.
Even when forced to go to bed earlier these children will not be sleepy and while they might stay in their room they will still not fall asleep until their later usual bedtime.

Educate and Teach Your Children of the Dangers of Inhalants Abuse The aim is to teach children to be safe, to be aware of predatory strangers, and to be self protective.
Teach your children they should never meet anyone in person that they've only communicated with online.
Teach your children how to interact safely with people they "meet" online.
Kids will always be kids, and parents should always take some responsibility in teaching their children how not to get involved in schoolyard antics such as bullying or harming others.

Allowing free access puts your child, your computer and your personal data at risk.

Some people think diet supplements improve symptoms of ADHD.
The use of these supplements as treatment for ADHD is based on theories that ADHD symptoms are caused by the lack of certain nutrients and minerals in the body.
Iron levels tend to be low in individuals with ADHD.
However, there is little evidence that a diet without sugar or additives help with the symptoms of ADHD.
Others proponents of dietary manipulations as alternative treatments for ADHD postulated that dietary sugar and simple carbohydrates could cause ADHD in children.

A parental right to educate one's children is a popular belief among homeschoolers (Benoit, 1997).
Homeschooling is an alternative method of teaching where the parent delivers an educational program to children at home.
A Utah mother of six assumed full responsibility for teaching her LD children to read.
Parents like that it tracks progress and helps children advance by clearly presenting and reinforcing each lesson.
Disorganized parents are also likely to have serious difficulties being in charge of an educational program.
All parents need is a basic education to be able to teach a child.

I think there is an extraordinarily unbalanced perception in our society of how much socializing children need. 
They often point out that children - especially little ones - need far less socializing than is normally expected in this day and in this country (and probably most other Western countries as well). 
Yes, we are social beings, but our primary and most important arena for socializing is the home. 
Even then, home is the most important place - and should, in my experience, be the main arena of life until  about the 9 year change.

They are parents who "come to their decision to home school with a broader interest in learning--they have professional training in education, they have close friends or relatives who are educators, they have read about education or child development, or they are involved with organizations that speak to the issue of childrearing. Nowadays, a lot of parents choose homeschooling as their option for their children's education.
Parents choose homeschooling for many different reasons.
Homeschooling is achievable for the majority of families, but it is not easy.
While there are many positive aspects of homeschooling, there are also the negative aspects of homeschooling.
Your finances need to be solidly grounded in order to be successful in homeschooling.
One great thing about having two or more children in a homeschooling setting is that the younger ones want to keep up with the older ones.

Carol Fraser Boles, the Literacy Specialist for the National Writing for Children Center, is a wonderful resource person for parents who are teaching their children to read or acting as a facilitator in the process. 
Carol is a former public school K-12 Reading Specialist and special education teacher, and she has written many articles on literacy. 
She also offers suggestions for books and resources on her website at www.carolfraserboles.com, as well as a page of 'literacy lingo' terms that are very helpful.

Discussing Concerns with Family Members I am concerned that my grandson may have signs of autism, but I am uncomfortable bringing this up with my son and daughter-in-law. 
Do you have any suggestions about how best to approach them? 
Answered by Peggy Halliday, MEd, BCBA (Virginia Institute of Autism) and David Celiberti, PhD, BCBA-D (President, Association for Science in Autism Treatment) It is natural to be unsure of how to share your concerns with your grandson's parents. 
As is the case with many concerned family members, you may worry that such a discussion may not be well received.

Not many parents are aware that their teen is "cutting", or is planning to run away.
The challenge facing many parents is great.
Teenagers do not always confide in their parents about situations that may be stressful or dangerous.
Each parent needs to clearly list and present to the teenager those issues that are non-negotiable.
The site covers a diverse number of relevant subjects on teenage behaviour and parenting strategies to help others cope with with defiant teens.

Net Smartz Teens NetSmartz Teens uses interactive tools to teach teens how to be safer on the Internet.
Use privacy settings to restrict who can access and post on your child's website.
Treat your children's online activities like you do their offline ones.
Kids in elementary grades can play games and learn about basic Internet principles and chat safety.
Keeping kids safe must be an ongoing effort through awareness, education and supervision.
Encourage your kids to share their gameplay experience with you.
Tell your kids to trust their gut if they have suspicions.

Children must be age five by September 30 to enter kindergarten.
Many parents with children poised to start school have adopted the same line of thinking.
Your child can only be older and more mature if other kids are younger and less mature.
Young children learn about numbers and math through their everyday activities.
Children entering at the K4 level shall be four by September 1.
Bullying is unfair and adults must take it seriously as early as in kindergarten.

David would be 5 in July. 
Full of enthusiasm, he confidently underwent spring kindergarten screening. 
The school psychologist explained that David completed the screening with average and above-average skills, but he had a summer birthday and he was a male. 
The psychologist and the gym teacher agreed that David would be more successful in school if he were to postpone kindergarten for 1 year. 
David’s experience has been repeated over and over by many children across the country.

I am looking for feedback from those families that may have had their child repeat kindergarten. The answers are not simple. Some children enter at age six. Could this be an advantage? Describes objects as being under or over something; or on or off Or will he get left behind by his more able peers? What do you think about this? We were told we were lucky when she was born; she made it! But developmentally they're where they should be."

Many nursery school programs around the country now offer an additional year for children who are age-appropriate for kindergarten, but who are not developmentally ready.
While kindergarten teachers commonly report that younger kids struggle their first year, research has also shown that "by third grade, there is no measurable academic advantage to delayed entry" and that "children who entered school relatively young did not appear to be disadvantaged academically in the long-run."
To be eligible for 4-year-old kindergarten, a child must be 4 by September 1 of the school year.

Keep in mind that children go through periods of adjustments and transitions, and their schoolwork may also become more challenging as a child progresses through school.
Children who usually have a healthy appetite may suddenly lose interest in eating.
They may occur suddenly or happen slowly over time.
Children may not completely understand what they are feeling, and may be less likely to report emotional pain.

Depression is a common disorder among children (less than 18 years).

Symptoms of depression in children may not be obvious .
Treatment of major depression is as effective for children as it is for adults.
Untreated depression can have important consequences for the child's well-being.
Depression is harmful whether or not a child has a chronic disease.
Therapy combined with antidepressants is thought to produce the best outcomes in children with depression.
Depression is not just an illness of the mind.
Your child's doctor will rule out any other physical causes of your child's symptoms.
Talk to your child to see how he or she is feeling.

In order to recognize depression in children, it is important to become aware of the the signs and symptoms to look for. 
The warning signs of depression in children fall basically into four different categories: emotional signs, cognitive signs (those involving thinking), physical complaints, and behavioral changes. 
Not every child who is depressed experiences every symptom. 
Typical moods or emotions experienced by children suffering from depression include: Sadness - The child may feel despondent and hopeless. 
They may cry easily.

Meta-analysis of CBT therapies that have been utilized in the treatment of adolescent depression revealed that 63% of individuals receiving some form of cognitive-behavioral therapy showed significant improvements.
Certain antidepressant medications, called selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors ( SSRIs ), can be beneficial to children and adolescents with depression.
Controlled clinical trials supporting the effectiveness of fluoxetine exist, but more research is needed to develop and test effective depression medications and psychosocial treatments for these children.

There is some evidence that if a child receives cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) in a group setting, it can help prevent or delay the onset of depression in a child or teen whose parent has depression (which puts the child at greater risk for becoming depressed).
Their intervention strategy focuses on increasing children's resilience to depression, especially with children who may be at high risk for developing the disorder (i.e., children of depressed parents).
Antidepressants are often used due to their success in adults or due to studies in the pediatric population.

Fears and Phobias can be resolved with hypnosis and hypnotherapy Hypnotherapy is an ideal option because it is safe, effective, and non-invasive.
If a parent is afraid of spiders then a child can learn that fear and it could develop into a phobia.
Hypnotherapy is effective at helping you to overcome your fear by treating the anxiety caused by the trigger, and by re-training the mind to remember the original trigger in a way that does not create anxiety.
Medication can be very effective in treating phobias, especially social phobia and agoraphobia.

Probably the best way to get rid of a phobia is to face your fear directly. 
Of course, you can't do that all at onceÃ¯Â¿Â½and you certainly can't do it by yourself. 
In cognitive-behavioral therapy, you meet for about 12 sessions (although social phobia may take more) with a trained mental health professional. 
He or she will ask you to confront whatever it is that you fear in a carefully planned way. 
First your mental health professional may ask you to see the object or situation in your imagination. 
Then he or she will ask you to look at pictures of what you fear.

Kids/people often need tangible consequences to stop a behavior (E.g. Natural consequences should not be used if they place a child in danger (an obvious example is allowing a young child to ride a bike on a busy street in which there is the possibility of getting hit by a car), but are appropriate in many other situations.
Rather than teaching kids how to change their behavior, spanking makes them fearful of their parents and merely teaches them to avoid getting caught.

Everyone wants to foster the reading in their children. 
This is true regardless of when the children begin to read. 
Whether the children begin to read before they are two or don't start to read until they start school, they are sure to enjoy these activities. 1. 
Provide Reading Material Children can't read if they don't have anything to read! We know that children in homes full of reading material are more likely to read themselves. 
Even if children aren't reading yet on their own, reading material should be available. 
Both books and magazines for children should be in the house.

(6)  Corporal punishment shall not be administered on a student whose parent or guardian has stated in writing that corporal punishment shall not be administered to that student.

In no case shall the school administrator, teacher or individual engaged in child care exercising special parental authority inflict corporal punishment upon the child.
Corporal punishment is not just a school issue involving students, but is a societal issue involving families and cultures.

Corporal punishment is a discipline method in which a supervising adult deliberately inflicts pain upon a child in response to a child's unacceptable behavior and/or inappropriate language. 
The immediate aims of such punishment are usually to halt the offense, prevent its recurrence and set an example for others. 
The purported long-term goal is to change the child's behavior and to make it more consistent with the adult's expectations.

This section discusses the use of school discipline policies, student conduct rules or school codes of behaviour.
All students, parents, and school personnel should be aware of the school's discipline policy or student conduct code.
While corporal punishment such as paddling, spanking and hitting students disappeared from private schools by the 1960s, it is still permitted in public schools in 20 states.
Shockingly, in twenty states, corporal punishment is still a legal and accepted form of discipline by teachers and school administrators.

A: Try taking a strengths-based approach to help your child develop confidence.
Shy children want to interact with unfamiliar others but don't because of their fear.
And being shy as a child does not mean that your child will have problems later in life.
Their teachers will know and love your child.
Minimizing or dismissing a child's problems can make a child avoid the issue or feel embarrassed.
Recognizing a Shy Kid Shy kids are easy to recognize in class and in social groups.
Social slipups are rarely as awful as kids imagine.
Kids need to know their feelings are normal.
